>>179839904
I'm in my 30s, I remember shit like this being the norm for home viewing and it was not better. Open matte shots made framing terrible and revealed countless errors, and pan and scan was a damn nightmare for a visual medium, with shots often missing their sides, and camera moves artificially added to account for the fact the full shot couldn't be seen on a square tv. The idea that 4:3 always means more picture is a myth pushed by youngsters who weren't around.
Anamorphic films like Die Hard were literally squished inward from the sides if you were going to watch them on a 4:3 video.
If something is intended to be 4:3, watch it 4:3. If it's intended to be widescreen, watch it widescreen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"The Thing" is a great barf-bag movie, all right, but is it any good? I found it disappointing, for two reasons: the superficial characterizations and the implausible behavior of the scientists on that icy outpost. Characters have never been Carpenter's strong point; he says he likes his movies to create emotions in his audiences, and I guess he'd rather see us jump six inches than get involved in the personalities of his characters. This time, though, despite some roughed-out typecasting and a few reliable stereotypes (the drunk, the psycho, the hero), he has populated his ice station with people whose primary purpose in life is to get jumped on from behind. The few scenes that develop characterizations are overwhelmed by the scenes in which the men are just setups for an attack by the Thing.

That leads us to the second problem, plausibility. We know that the Thing likes to wait until a character is alone, and then pounce, digest, and imitate him--by the time you see Doc again, is he still Doc, or is he the Thing? Well, the obvious defense against this problem is a watertight buddy system, but, time and time again, Carpenter allows his characters to wander off alone and come back with silly grins on their faces, until we've lost count of who may have been infected, and who hasn't. That takes the fun away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: "The Thing" is basically, then, just a geek show, a gross-out movie in which teenagers can dare one another to watch the screen. There's nothing wrong with that; I like being scared and I was scared by many scenes in "The Thing." But it seems clear that Carpenter made his choice early on to concentrate on the special effects and the technology and to allow the story and people to become secondary. Because this material has been done before, and better, especially in the original "The Thing" and in "Alien," there's no need to see this version unless you are interested in what the Thing might look like while starting from anonymous greasy organs extruding giant crab legs and transmuting itself into a dog. Amazingly, I'll bet that thousands, if not millions, of moviegoers are interested in seeing just that.

You misunderstand how these positions work anon
The writer provides a script true to the original work, full of wit and charm

The producer snorts cocaine, scribbles over the script, and threatens to cut budget if they disobey his great ideas.
The director decides that being faithful isn't enough, he needs to put his own spin on things and include social activism into the work
the hiring director takes whoever's willing to suck them off them most/has friends willing to bribe him
Another executive decides he needs to intervene, throws out shitty ideas, to which the sycophants in the company scream "you're so amazing!" and they get put into play
>the diversity committee looks for places to insert more niggers, and rewrite the script for le ebin "yass kween" moments.
The test audience, which isn't regular people, but a bunch of snobby art critics and people who don't even like the source material, demand changes be made just for them.
The media executives do a final pass-over, cut shit at random, blow coke and give anal to the one extra willing to be railed on the boardroom table, and then make a last-minute call to change half the episodes before boarding their private jet to epstein island.
tl;dr consultant means jack shit

It occurs to me a decent adaptation of Bebop could have really landed with modern people. The story is more relevant than ever.

Faye is treated like a source of profit and scammed as soon as she's revived. No one gives a shit about the culture shock she must feel or that she might be able to fill in missing parts of the historical record since the gate disaster. (wealthcare, treatment of the elderly)

Ed takes off to find her "real dad" even though he's a deadbeat who doesn't care about her. (the "found family" is a Reddit meme, you will die alone if you don't have bio-kids)

"Get woke, go broke" has nothing to do with anything. Culture has just become diffused as people can just get everything they want when they want it through a variety of means. Movies have held on for a little while longer but it feels like that's mostly gone away post-Endgame. The post-Endgame MCU certainly doesn't have the same cultural penetration as the previous 12 years of movies did. I mean the Avatar sequel has done over $2 billion but I haven't actually heard anyone talk about it. It made all this money but it's presence in the cultural sphere is just not there the way the first one's was despite making more money.

>"I think about the day when she was in the spirit world, and she was meeting her mother, and Sigourney had to quickly switch back and forth between them. >dont people just wake up from seizures on their own?
They do (provided the seizure isn't particularly severe) but the cause can be up for question. We can assume Kiri has never had a seizure before, so a sudden onset like that could be signs of something else, like a brain tumour or blood clot/brain bleed, which is what Norm and Max checked for when they got there. Jake also probably knows extremely little about Na'vi Biology, and it's not like anyone of the Na'vi have done detailed autopsy or biological research themselves, for all he knew mixing human and Na'vi DNA into an Avatar and then having it give birth could lead to genetic instability in the offspring. So really calling Norm was the smartest thing Jake did the whole film.

>Speaking with the British newspaper The Times, Alsop shared that she initially found out about the film in August, and was shocked that many “superficial aspects” lined up with her life. >However, Alsop stated that once she saw the movie, she was “no longer concerned, I was offended.” She added, “I was offended as a woman, I was offended as a conductor, I was offended as a lesbian.”

>Specifically, Alsop said it was “heartbreaking” to see the film’s depiction of a woman in such a role being an abuser. “I think all women and all feminists should be bothered by that kind of depiction because it’s not really about women conductors, is it? >>179834159
Dunno, some of the best shows I've watched included preachy nonsense. Only the topics have shifted.
70s/80s it was about women in the workplace; WKRP in Cincinnati for example had the secretary of the radio station be the highest paid employee, she was sexy and knew it but also brilliant, witty, sarcastic, and savvy in business.
Cheers had the early dichotomy of Educated Gal vs Blue Collar crowd, Diane and Carla respectively, but they were both waitresses so it wasn't as on the nose-- until Rebecca Howe comes and takes over, then the show became something much different.
By the late 80s you have "women are firmly represented in the workplace now" with Roseanne, Seinfeld, Growing Pains.

This also began the first salvo of "Gay Acceptance" which became much bigger in the 90s.
Cheers had a gay episode, Frasier, Seinfeld, Friends, Step by Step. By the late 90s Gay Acceptance was so massive there would be gay characters; Just Shoot Me, Will and Grace, Roseanne.
Early 00s we start getting into a bit of cultural whiplash. 9/11 happened early into the 2000s which fucked with American sensibilities-- comedies became much more popular as an outlet, and not just sitcoms with family life or coworkers working, but Comedy Shows. Stand up comedy was getting more popular. Stuff became a bit more crude, lewd, lascivious, people were faggots or retards, and we got the sketch comedy of WKUK, Chappelle's Show, that trickled down into kid's shows like All That, The Amanda Show.
Dramas pivoted to military, cops, thrillers, like 24-- or they'd have overt references to 9/11 or the war like The Sopranos and The Wire.
9/11 to the Writer's Strike is basically its own generation of culture. Anti-heroes become the norm.

Post-writer's strike/financial crisis we saw a massive doubling down of anti-heroes or morally grey main characters. And then Marvel came along as we pivoted into the 10s which beget PC culture, trans acceptance, and a type of "we should undo that 2001-2009 era"

If they have the original reel, there's ways to do it, but I'm not aware of the detailed process. That's actually a good question and I'll search about it today.
If they don't, they grab the best digital copy they have and do one of 2 things. Do a really sloppy job by just scaling it up, applying a filter that usually removes the grain and smoothens things out and upmix the audio or, if they decide to do a decent job, the director sits down with whoever is doing post-processing and they go over each scene to make sure the best filters, colors and sound adjustments are made, but even this might not be 100% decent.
At least that's my understanding from the few videos I've seen.
